Home Defence.Function of thePolice and CivilDefenceServices.(previous reference:W.M. (40) 213thConclusions,Minute 10.)10. The War Cabinet again considered the orders to the policeif they should find themselves behind the enemy lines.The Home Secretary said that he had now had an opportunityof discussing the position with the Commissioner of Police of the metropolis and the Inspectors of Constabulary. The chief constables with whom the Inspectors had been in touch had allexpressed satisfaction with the instructions issued, which cleared up points which had previously been in doubt.Discussion followed on the wording of paragraph 4 (c) of theinstructions issued to the police in case of invasion. (these instructions laid it down that, if any elements of the civil popula-tion remained in an enemy occupied area, the rearguard of thepolice should also remain behind, and that the senior officer of thepolice should offer the assistance of the police in maintaining order,any arms previously not handed over to the military authoritiesbeing surrendered.) Objection was felt to the issue of an orderinstructing the police to put themselves under the order of theenemy and to give them assistance in any circumstances whatever.It was pointed out that these orders applied only to the rear-guard of the police, and that, if effective steps were to be taken toensure that the civil population "stayed put " and did not obstruct the roads, a proportion of the police must stay behind until theenemy occupation became effective. The instructions on this matter had been issued as a secret document, but had apparently got intohands for which they were not intended. It was most important to do nothing which might suggest the idea of retreat. There wasno room for retreat in these islands, and nothing short of themost vigorous and sustained resistance should be suggested orcountenanced in any instruction. This paragraph should, therefore,be amended so as to make it clear that the function of any policeleft behind should be to give all possible help to the civil population,without at the same time assisting the enemy.In discussion it was suggested that, as soon as invasion tookplace, the police should become part of the Armed Forces of theCrown. Various difficulties were pointed out. Thus many of thepolice were over the age of compulsory military service, or werephysically unfit and untrained to be soldiers. In any case, a civilian body could hardly be converted as a whole and automaticallyinto a combatant force. In actual practice the younger men trained in the use of arms would be withdrawn with their arms as far aspossible, leaving older and unarmed men behind. Means might,perhaps, be found of making this arrangement rather more explicit.Reference was also made to the position of members of the fire Brigade and A.R.P. Services. Many men had joined these services before the Home Guard had been formed and would nowlike to transfer to combatant duties. From the point of view of resisting invasion they should be encouraged to do so. On the otherhand, we had had no experience yet of heavy air attack, which would call for the services of able-bodied men in the Fire Brigade andA.R.P. squads. Probably the best solution would lie in somereciprocal arrangement between the Home Guard and the Air RaidPrecautions Services.The War Cabinet-(1) Invited the Home Secretary,Secretary of State for War,of the Instructions to police the light of the discussion.(2) Invited the Home Secretary to of State for War in regard to of the Air Raid Precautionsfor combatant service in thein consultation with theto re-draft paragraph 4 (c)in the event of Invasion inconsult with the secretary the availability of members and Fire Brigade Servicesevent of Invasion.Richmond Terrace, S.W. 1,August 5, 1940.
